Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in requiring a psychological report for 'compelling reasons' claims under IRPA s. 108(4)
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 108(4)
Evidence_Assessment: Lack of psychological evidence was cited as a reason for dismissal
Decision_Outcome: RAD dismissed the appeal due to lack of psychological evidence
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate compelling reasons for reconsideration
Credibility_Factor: Fear of FGM by the Mungiki gang
Legal_Rule: Under IRPA s. 108(4), refugee claims can be reconsidered if there are compelling reasons, without requiring psychological reports
Procedural_Issue: Requirement of psychological report not mandated by law
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to risk of Female Genital Mutilation (FGM)
Outcome_on_Merits: Original claim rejected by RPD; appeal dismissed by RAD
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: RAD's imposition of an extralegal requirement undermined fairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Claim of fear of FGM, absence of psychological report
Legal_Framework: IRPA, Canadian immigration and refugee law
Court_Result: Federal Court allowed judicial review, remitted matter to a different RAD panel
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of appeal by a different RAD panel
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Risk of FGM by non-state actor (Mungiki gang)
Applicable_Process: Refugee appeal and judicial review process
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Reconsideration of refugee claim on remittal
Governing_Rule: IRPA s. 108(4) – compelling reasons for reconsideration
